Let $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ be two monic cubic polynomials, and let $r$ be a real number.  Two of the roots of $f(x)$ are $r + 1$ and $r + 7.$  Two of the roots of $g(x)$ are $r + 3$ and $r + 9,$ and
\[f(x) - g(x) = r\]for all real numbers $x.$  Find $r.$
inference:
Since two of the roots of $f(x)$ are $r+1$ and $r+7$, we can write 
$$f(x)=a(x-(r+1))(x-(r+7))$$
for some constant $a$.  Similarly, we can write 
$$g(x)=b(x-(r+3))(x-(r+9))$$
for some constant $b$.  Then
$$f(x)-g(x)=a(x-(r+1))(x-(r+7))-b(x-(r+3))(x-(r+9)).$$
Since $f(x)-g(x)=r$ for all $x$, we have
$$\begin{split} r &= a(x-(r+1))(x-(r+7))-b(x-(r+3))(x-(r+9)) \\\ & = a(x^2-(2r+8)x+(r+1)(r+7)) \\\ & \quad -b(x^2-(2r+12)x+(r+3)(r+9))  \\\ & = (a-b)x^2 + (2a+2b)rx + (a(r+1)(r+7)-b(r+3)(r+9)) \end{split}$$
for all $x$.  Equating the coefficients of $x^2$, $x$, and the constant term on the left and right sides of the equation, we have
$$\begin{split} a-b &= 0, \\\ 2a+2b & = 0, \\\ a(r+1)(r+7) - b(r+3)(r+9) & = r.  \end{split}$$
The first two equations yield $a=b$.  Substituting this into the third equation, we have
$$a(r+1)(r+7) - a(r+3)(r+9) = r.$$
Simplifying, we obtain
$$4a = r \qquad \Rightarrow \qquad r = \boxed{4}.$$
Final Answer: $\boxed{4}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
By Factor Theorem,
\[f(x) = (x - r - 1)(x - r - 7)(x - a)\]and
\[g(x) = (x - r - 3)(x - r - 9)(x - b)\]for some real numbers $a$ and $b.$

Then
\[f(x) - g(x) = (x - r - 1)(x - r - 7)(x - a) - (x - r - 3)(x - r - 9)(x - b) = r\]for all $x.$

Setting $x = r + 3,$ we get
\[(2)(-4)(r + 3 - a) = r.\]Setting $x = r + 9,$ we get
\[(8)(2)(r + 9 - a) = r.\]Then $-8r - 24 + 8a = r$ and $16r + 144 - 16a = r,$ so
\begin{align*}
8a - 9r &= 24, \\
-16a + 15r &= -144.
\end{align*}Solving, we find $r = \boxed{32}.$
